CATEGORY-TYPE: Dry weight, yield and yield components
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the above-ground biomass (except roots) in dry weight, in kilograms of dry matter per hectare. Monitoring this metric helps farmers assess their crops' growth and health, providing insights into biomass production and potential yield.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: This is above ground biomass (except roots) in dry weight. If farmer is intersted in biomass production (e.g., biofuel crops), then he might ask what is my above-ground biomass production per unit area?
QUESTIONS: What would be my above-ground biomass production per unit area?

CATEGORY-TYPE: Dry weight, yield and yield components
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total weight of a crop harvested per hectare, in kilograms of dry matter. It represents the portion of the crop that remains after all water content has been removed, providing a consistent basis for comparing yields across different conditions.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Farmer often ask this question. What is my crop yield at maturity?
QUESTIONS: What would be my crop yield at maturity?

CATEGORY-TYPE: Dry weight, yield and yield components
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total weight of a crop harvested per hectare, in kilograms of dry matter (dm). It represents the portion of the crop that remains after all water content has been removed, providing a consistent basis for comparing yields across different conditions.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer harvest very late after maturity or due to harvesting losses harvest yield may differ from yield at maturity. So farmer might give you a harvest date and ask what would be my yield on this date of harvest.
QUESTIONS: How much yield would I be able to harvest by a certain harvest date?

CATEGORY-TYPE: Dry weight, yield and yield components
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the ratio between the harvest's dry weight and the crop biomass's total dry weight (including the harvest). It is the proportion of the above-ground biomass (in the case of cereals) that is found in the grain, i.e., a harvest index of 33 percent, results in a ratio of 2 kg straw:1 kg grain (FAO, 2022)
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Some farmers may ask what is my harvest index. It is the ratio between dry weight of the harvest and total dry weight of the crop biomass (including the harvest)
QUESTIONS: What would be my harvest index by the time the crop matures?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total number of irrigation events applied to a crop during its growing season. It includes all instances where water is supplied to the crop, whether through manual scheduling based on field records or automated systems that trigger irrigation based on specific criteria such as soil moisture levels or evapotranspiration rates.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: How many time I should apply irrigation? When I should apply irrigation? How much I should apply?
QUESTIONS: What should be the optimum amount of irrigation applications?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total volume of water used in a crop field through irrigation over an entire growing season, measured in millimeters. This measurement encompasses all irrigation events and accounts for water losses during application, such as evaporation, runoff, or deep percolation.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What was my seasonal total irrigation requirement?
QUESTIONS: What would be my total irrigation requirement by the end of the season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the cumulative amount of rainfall, measured in millimeters, that a crop receives from the start of the simulation period until the harvest date. This metric is crucial for understanding the water availability during the crop's growth cycle, significantly influencing crop development and yield outcomes.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What was the total precipitation during the growing season?
QUESTIONS: What would be the total precipitation amount during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the cumulative amount of water, measured in millimeters, that is transferred from the soil and crop surfaces to the atmosphere through the combined processes of evaporation and transpiration during the entire growing season from the start of the simulation until harvest.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What was the total evapotraspiration during the growing season?
QUESTIONS: What would be the total evapotranspiration amount during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of water, measured in millimeters, that flows over the soil surface and exits the field during a crop's growing season. This runoff occurs when rainfall or irrigation exceeds the soil's infiltration capacity, leading to excess water moving across the land.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What was the surface runoff during the growing season? - if someone interested on improving drainage on their farm etc….
QUESTIONS: What will be the amount of water surface runoff by the end of the season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of water, measured in millimeters, that moves downward through the soil profile beyond the root zone during a crop's growing season. This drainage occurs when rainfall or irrigation exceeds the soil's water-holding capacity, leading to percolation of excess water and even waterlogging.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What was the drainage during the growing season? - if someone interested on improving drainage on their farm etc….
QUESTIONS: What will be the amount of water drained during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of soil water available for plant uptake at the time of crop maturity, measured in millimeters. This metric indicates the remaining usable water in the soil profile when the crop reaches its final growth stage.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: This is amount of water available in the soil profile for crop use at the time of crop maturity. Some of them may be intetrsted to know to unserstand drought conditions etc….
QUESTIONS: What would be the amount of water available in the soil profile for crop use at the time of crop maturity?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total number of nitrogen fertilizer applications made to a crop during its growing season. This count includes all instances where nitrogen is supplied to the crop, regardless of the method or form of application.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: How many times and when I should apply N fertilizer
QUESTIONS: How many times would I need to apply nitrogen-fertilizer by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied to a crop field during a growing season, measured in kilograms of nitrogen per hectare. Inorganic nitrogen fertilizers include compounds such as urea, ammonium nitrate, and ammonium sulfate, which provide readily available nitrogen to plants.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What is the amount of N fertilizer required to be applied during the growing season?
QUESTIONS: What would be the required amount of nitrogen-fertilizer to apply during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of atmospheric nitrogen that leguminous crops, such as soybeans or alfalfa, convert into a usable form through biological nitrogen fixation during a single growing season. This process allows these crops to meet a significant portion of their nitrogen requirements without relying solely on soil nitrogen or external fertilizers.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Legume crops such as soybean can fix nitrogen in the soil. So farmers can ask how much N was fixed if they cultiavte soybean/alfalfa so they can cut down that amount during the next season planting
QUESTIONS: How much nitrogen would be fixed by the crop by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of nitrogen absorbed by a crop from the soil throughout its growing season, measured in kilograms of nitrogen per hectare. This metric encompasses all nitrogen sources available to the plant, including soil reserves, applied fertilizers, and atmospheric deposition.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Some farmers want to ask in the amount applied how much was taken by my crop?
QUESTIONS: How much nitrogen would my crop absorb by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of nitrogen, measured in kilograms per hectare, that moves beyond the root zone into deeper soil layers or groundwater during a crop's growing season. This leaching typically occurs when rainfall or irrigation exceeds the soil's water-holding capacity, causing soluble nitrogen compounds, such as nitrates, to be carried downward.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer concerns about the environment then he/she might ask how much was lost due to leaching during the season.
QUESTIONS: How much nitrogen was lost due to leaching during the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of inorganic nitrogen present in the soil, measured in kilograms per hectare, when the crop reaches full maturity. Inorganic nitrogen includes forms such as nitrate and ammonium. For example, if a farmer needs to understand next season's N application, this information will be helpful to him.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: refers to the amount of inorganic nitrogen (nitrate and ammonium) present in the soil at the time of crop maturity. If farmer need to have some understanding for next season N application he might ask
QUESTIONS: How much inorganic nitrogen would remain present in the soil by the time the crop matures?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: N2OEM the amount of nitrogen oxide gas emissions during the season. This gas is responsible for global warming. For example, if a farmer is concerned about the environment, they might ask how much was lost due to N2O gas emissions during the season.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer concerns about the environment then he/she might ask how much was lost due to N2O gas emissions during the season. This gas is responsible for global warming
QUESTIONS: How much Nitrous oxide would be emitted by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total count of phosphorus fertilizer applications made to a crop during its growing season. Phosphorus is a primary nutrient supporting root development and plant energy transfer. Accurately tracking the number of phosphorus applications is essential for evaluating nutrient management practices and their impact on crop performance.

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of inorganic phosphorus fertilizer applied to a crop field during a growing season, measured in kilograms of phosphorus per hectare. Inorganic phosphorus fertilizers, such as superphosphate or diammonium phosphate, provide readily available phosphorus to plants.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What is the amount of P fertilizer required to be applied during the growing season?
QUESTIONS: What would be the required amount of phosphorus-fertilizer to apply during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of phosphorus absorbed by a crop from the soil over the entire growing season, measured in kilograms of phosphorus per hectare. Phosphorus is essential for evaluating nutrient management practices and their impact on crop performance.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Some farmers want to ask in the amount applied how much was taken by my crop?
QUESTIONS: How much phosphorus would my crop absorb by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of phosphorus remaining in the soil, measured in kilograms per hectare, when the crop reaches full maturity. This measurement includes both inorganic and organic phosphorus forms available for plant uptake.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: refers to the amount of P present in the soil at the time of crop maturity. If farmer need to have some understanding for next season P application he might ask

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total count of potassium fertilizer applications made to a crop during its growing season. Potassium (K) is an essential nutrient that plays a vital role in various plant physiological processes, including water regulation, enzyme activation, and photosynthesis.

QUESTIONS: How many times would I need to apply potassium-fertilizer?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of inorganic potassium fertilizer applied to a crop field during a growing season, measured in kilograms of potassium per hectare. Inorganic potassium fertilizers, such as potassium chloride (Muriate of Potash) or potassium sulfate, provide readily available potassium to plants, essential for various physiological functions, including enzyme activation, photosynthesis, and water regulation.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What is the amount of K fertilizer required to be applied during the growing season?
QUESTIONS: What is the required amount of potassium-fertilizer  to be applied during the growing season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total amount of potassium absorbed by a crop from the soil over the entire growing or cropping season, measured in kilograms of potassium per hectare. Potassium is essential in various plant physiological processes, including enzyme activation, photosynthesis, and water regulation.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: Some farmers want to ask in the amount applied how much was taken by my crop?
QUESTIONS: How much potassium would my crop absorb by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of potassium remaining in the soil, measured in kilograms per hectare, when the crop reaches full maturity. This measurement includes both inorganic and organic potassium forms available for plant uptake. For example, a farmer may be interested if they need some understanding of next season's potassium (K) applications.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: refers to the amount of K present in the soil at the time of crop maturity. If farmer need to have some understanding for next season K application he might ask

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: Crop residue is all the remaining crop parts after you remove the yield (seeds/grains) from the field. It is measured in kilograms per hectare. It is essential for maintaining soil organic matter, enhancing soil fertility, and improving soil structure.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: How much crop residue I should apply? Or keep in the field. Crop residue is all the remaining crop parts after you takeout the yield (seeds/grains) from the field
QUESTIONS: How much crop residue I should apply or keep in the field?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the amount of carbon dioxide gas released into the atmosphere from various sources within the agricultural system. For example, if a farmer is very concerned about ecological footprint, etc., he might want to ask how much CO2 is emitted during the season.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer is very concern about ecological footprint and etc then he might want to ask how much CO2 emiited during the season
QUESTIONS: How much carbon dioxyde would be emitted by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: a metric that quantifies the efficiency of irrigation water use in crop production. It represents the dry matter (DM) yield produced per hectare for each millimeter of irrigation water applied. For example, if the crop is grown for biomass, the farmer can ask what dry matter irrigation productivity is.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: if the crop is grown for biomass then farmer can ask what is dry matter irrigation productivity
QUESTIONS: What would be the dry matter-to-irrigation productivity value?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: a metric that quantifies the efficiency with which a crop converts water lost through evapotranspiration (ET) into harvested yield. It represents the crop yield produced per hectare for each millimeter of water transpired and evaporated during the growing season. Furthermore, generally known as crop water productivity, so farmers want to ask what crop water productivity is.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: This is generally known as crop water productivity so farmer want to ask what was the crop water productivity
QUESTIONS: What would be the crop water productivity by the end of the cropping season?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: measures the efficiency with which applied irrigation water contributes to crop yield. It indicates the amount or yield of the crop in kilogram produced per hectare for each millimeter of irrigation water supplied during the growing season. It can help provide insights into how much yield can be produced per unit of applied irrigation.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: How much yield I can produce per unit irrigation?
QUESTIONS: How much yield can I produce per unit of irrigated area?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: a metric that quantifies the efficiency with which a crop converts applied nitrogen fertilizer into dry matter. It represents the dry matter produced per kilogram of nitrogen fertilizer applied. For example, if a farmer is interested in producing biomass, he might ask how much biomass I could produce per unit N fertilizer application.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer inteterested in producing the biomass he might ask how much biomass I could producer per unit N fertilizer application
QUESTIONS: How much biomass could I produce per unit of Nitrogen fertilizer application?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: measures how effectively a crop converts applied nitrogen (N) fertilizer into harvested yield. It represents the crop yield produced per kilogram of nitrogen fertilizer applied (in kilogram).
Dr. Rasu Explantion: How much yield I can produce per unit N fertilizer?
QUESTIONS: How much yield could I produce per unit of Nitrogen fertilizer?

CATEGORY: Number of days from planting to harvest (d)
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the total duration, measured in days, between the planting date and the harvest date of a crop. This period encompasses the entire growth cycle, including germination, vegetative growth, flowering, and maturation. Accurately determining this duration is crucial for effective crop management, as it influences the scheduling of field operations, resource allocation, and overall yield optimization.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: What will be the crop duration?
QUESTIONS: What would be the duration of the cropping season, from planting to harvest?

CATEGORY: Total season precipitation (mm), planting to harvest
CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the cumulative amount of rainfall, measured in millimeters, that a crop field receives from the planting date until the harvest date. For example, if a farmer needs to understand drought conditions, he might want to know the total seasonal precipitation.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer needs to have an understanding of drought conditions he might want to know what was the total seasonal precipitation
QUESTIONS: What would be the total precipitation by the end of the cropping season (from planting to harvest)?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the cumulative amount of water, measured in millimeters, that is transferred from the soil and crop surfaces to the atmosphere through the combined processes of evaporation and transpiration during the entire growing season, from planting to harvest. Helpful to understand drought conditions.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: If farmer needs to have an understanding of drought conditions he might want to know what was the total seasonal ET
QUESTIONS: What would be the total evapotranspiration by the end of the cropping season (from planting to harvest)?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the specific day a crop reaches its flowering stage. Accurately recording the anthesis date is essential for understanding the crop's development timeline, scheduling management practices, and predicting harvest dates.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: When my crops will flower
QUESTIONS: When will my crop start flowering?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: the crop maturity date; when a crop fully develops and its seeds or fruits have accumulated maximum dry weight. At this stage, the crop no longer depends on the plant for nutrients, and harvesting can commence without affecting yield or quality.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: When my crops would mature
QUESTIONS: By which date would my crop mature?

CATEGORY_DEFINITIONS: This the specific day when a crop is collected from the field after reaching its desired maturity. This date is crucial for accurately modeling crop growth cycles, assessing yield outcomes, and evaluating the effectiveness of agricultural practices.
Dr. Rasu Explantion: When I would be able to harvest
QUESTIONS: When would I be able to harvest?
